sections.title: Photostability and Signal Strength Advantages
sections.tldr: Semiconducting polymers demonstrate exceptional photostability and significantly stronger signal generation compared to conventional imaging agents, allowing for extended imaging sessions without degradation. Their superior brightness enables detection of cancer cells with fluorescence intensity up to 25 times higher than quantum dots and 18 times higher than conventional dyes, making them ideal for sensitive tumor detection applications. (10 sources)
sections.text:
Semiconducting polymer nanoparticles (SPNs) exhibit remarkable photostability that significantly surpasses traditional tumor detection materials, enabling prolonged imaging sessions without signal deterioration. Unlike many organic dyes that rapidly photobleach, SPNs demonstrate strong resistance to photodegradation and oxidation, allowing for continuous monitoring of tumors over extended periods <Paper corpusId="4107691" paperTitle="(Pu et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper>. This exceptional stability has facilitated the development of the first near-infrared ratiometric photoacoustic probes for real-time imaging of reactive oxygen species—critical mediators in various disease processes including cancer <Paper corpusId="4107691" paperTitle="(Pu et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="265229155" paperTitle="(Kumar et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>.

The signal strength of SPNs represents another significant advantage over conventional imaging agents. Studies have demonstrated that polymer dot-labeled cancer cells exhibit fluorescence intensity 25 times higher than quantum dot-labeled cells and 18 times higher than Alexa Fluor-labeled cells in flow cytometry analysis <Paper corpusId="209392700" paperTitle="(Zhang et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>. This dramatically enhanced brightness enables more sensitive detection of small tumor cell populations, a critical factor for early cancer diagnosis when malignancies are in their initial stages.

In photoacoustic imaging applications, SPNs produce wider and more stable photoacoustic signals with significantly higher detection sensitivity compared to commonly used contrast agents such as single-wall carbon nanotubes and gold nanorods on a per mass basis <Paper corpusId="155642523" paperTitle="(Gargiulo et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="4107691" paperTitle="(Pu et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper>. This superior signal generation capability has permitted whole-body lymph node mapping in living mice at remarkably low injection doses <Paper corpusId="4107691" paperTitle="(Pu et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper>, demonstrating the efficiency with which these materials can be utilized for comprehensive tumor detection and metastasis monitoring.

The enhanced signal strength of SPNs stems largely from their unique structural properties. Their delocalized π-electron systems contribute to their remarkable optical features, which can be further amplified through structural engineering to enhance photoacoustic brightness for improved in vivo imaging sensitivity <Paper corpusId="250996126" paperTitle="(Hui et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>. These modifications have enabled SPNs to function as activatable probes that provide quantifiable real-time information on pathological status at the molecular level <Paper corpusId="250996126" paperTitle="(Hui et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>, offering more detailed insights into tumor biology than conventional imaging approaches.

For deep-tissue imaging applications, particularly in challenging contexts such as brain tumor visualization, SPNs demonstrate exceptional efficacy due to their combination of photostability and signal strength. When designed to absorb in the second near-infrared window (NIR-II), these materials demonstrate excellent photoacoustic and photothermal performance while maintaining high photostability <Paper corpusId="220371348" paperTitle="(Wen et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="276809915" paperTitle="(Rizwan et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper>. This enables effective accumulation in both subcutaneous tumors and brain tumors upon intravenous injection, facilitating efficient photoacoustic-guided therapy toward gliomas under NIR-II light irradiation <Paper corpusId="220371348" paperTitle="(Wen et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>.

The combination of exceptional photostability and strong signal generation positions SPNs as particularly valuable for diagnosing disease conditions involving reactive oxygen species, including tumor metastasis, cardiovascular diseases, and metabolic disorders <Paper corpusId="265298479" paperTitle="(Sridharan et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="253267881" paperTitle="(Jiang et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>. The ability of these materials to maintain consistent signal output during extended imaging sessions provides reliable data for assessing disease progression and treatment response, addressing a significant limitation of conventional fluorescent probes that suffer from photobleaching during prolonged use.

Moreover, the excellent photostability of SPNs contributes to their emerging role as theranostic platforms. When combined with therapeutic agents, these nanoparticles can simultaneously provide high-quality imaging for tumor detection and deliver targeted treatment, with their sustained signal output enabling real-time monitoring of therapeutic efficacy <Paper corpusId="272668437" paperTitle="(Yin et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="265229155" paperTitle="(Kumar et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. This dual functionality represents a significant advancement over traditional imaging agents that lack therapeutic capabilities or suffer from signal degradation during longitudinal studies.

paper.title: Gold Polymer Nanomaterials: A Promising Approach for Enhanced Biomolecular Imaging

snippets: Pu and colleagues have introduced semiconducting polymer nanoparticles prepared from poly(cyclopentadithiophene-alt-benzothiadiazole) and poly(acenaphthothienopyrazine-alt-benzodithiophene) which absorb near-infrared light as innovative contrast agents for photoacoustic molecular imaging (Pu et al., 2014). These nanoparticles outperformed traditional agents like gold nanorods and single-walled carbon nanotubes, delivering enhanced signal strength and enabling real-time, in vivo imaging of reactive oxygen species. When combined with therapeutic agents, this platform holds significant potential as a robust theranostic tool.

paper.title: Looking deep inside tissue with photoacoustic molecular probes: a review

snippets: The advantages of SPNs are numerous and include large absorption coefficient, tunable absorption, high photostability, low toxicity, (Upputuri et al., 2020) high structural flexibility, small size, and higher PA signal generation than single-wall carbon nanotubes (SWNTs) and AuNRs. (Pu et al., 2014) As an imaging probe to localize specific diseases or tissues, SPNs can produce PA signals in the sites of interest, relying on simple accumulation via the retention effect or receptor binding on the cell surface. This strategy leads to the application of LN mapping, (Pu et al., 2014) in vivo tumor-targeted imaging, (Ding et al., 2021)(Wen et al., 2020)(Dong et al., 2018) cell tracking, (Li et al., 2021) and ROS mapping. (Zhang et al., 2017)

Other than the simple accumulation of agents, SPNs also can be employed as activable PA probes with biomarker-triggered signals, which offer measurable and quantifiable real-time information on pathological status at the molecular level.

paper.title: Effective Phototheranostics of Brain Tumor Assisted by Near-Infrared-II Light-Responsive Semiconducting Polymer Nanoparticles.

snippets: Precise diagnosis and effective treatment of gliomas still remain a huge challenge. Photoacoustic-guided photothermal therapy (PTT) has unique advantages over conventional techniques for brain tumor theranostics, but existing nano-agents for PAI-guided PTT are mainly organic small molecules or inorganic nanoparticles, which have the limitations of poor photostability and biocompatibility. Besides, the restricted absorption in the first near-infrared window (NIR-I) of most existing nano-agents compromises their effectiveness for deep tissue PAI and PTT. We herein develop novel semiconducting polymer nanoparticles (SPNs) that are strongly absorptive in the second near-infrared window (NIR-II) to alleviate these problems. With the merits of excellent photoacoustic and photothermal performance, high photostability, proper size, and low toxicity, SPNs not only show efficient cellular uptake for PAI and PTT toward U87 glioma cells but also demonstrate effective accumulation in both subcutaneous tumor and brain tumor upon intravenous injection, thereby realizing efficient PAI-guided PTT toward gliomas under NIR-II light irradiation.

paper.title: Nanophotonic-enhanced photoacoustic imaging for brain tumor detection

snippets: Semiconducting polymer nanoparticles have emerged as promising contrast agents for PA imaging due to their efficient photothermal conversion (Wen et al., 2020). These nanoparticles, utilizing electron donor and acceptor pairs with π-conjugated polymer backbones, exhibit excellent photostability, NIR absorption and enhanced PA effects in brain tumor imaging (Hu et al., 2024). Fan et al. established perylene-3,4,9,10-tetracarboxylic diimide (PDI) nanoparticles, featuring a tertiary amine electron donor and a diimide electron acceptor, for deep brain tumor imaging (Fig. 10a) (Fan et al., 2015). Modified with DSPE-mPEG 5000 for water stability, these PDI nanoparticles showed enhanced PA signals in animal models with orthotopic glioblastoma upon continuous 700 nm laser irradiation, highlighting their efficacy through EPR effect and low toxicity (Fig. 10b).

snippets: In addition to their exceptional photostability and biocompatibility, semiconducting polymers possess distinct advantages over the other nanoparticles in PA applications (Upputuri et al., 2020). Successful detection of reactive oxygen species (ROS) using polymeric nanoparticles as nanoprobes has demonstrated that, these nanoparticles can be an excellent tool for the diagnosis of disease conditions such as tumor metastasis, cardiovascular diseases, diabetes, obesity and etc., that involves ROS guided/influenced pathophysiological events (Jiang et al., 2022).

paper.title: Nanomaterials for NIR‐II Photoacoustic Imaging

snippets: Compared with the photoacoustic imaging (PAI) in the first near‐infrared window (NIR‐I, 700–1000 nm), the PAI in the second near‐infrared window (NIR‐II, 1000–1700 nm) has the advantages of less background noise, deeper tissue penetration, and larger maximum permissible exposure, which has been become a research hotspot. In this review, the recent advances in nanomaterials for NIR‐II PAI are summarized, including the advantages of NIR‐II PAI and the applications of nanomaterials‐based NIR‐II PAI in biomedical field. The nanomaterials‐based PA contrast agents are classified into three categories, including organic (such as assembled small molecules, conjugated polymers, semiconducting polymers, and phthalocyanines), inorganic (such as metal sulfides, noble metals, carbon nanomaterials, quantum dots, 2D transition metal carbides and nitrides [MXenes], and semimetals), or organic/inorganic hybrid nanomaterials, which are mainly used for imaging and diagnosis of tumor tissues, brain vasculature, inflammation, and other tissues, as well as the monitoring of catalytic reaction processes in vivo. Moreover, the opportunities and challenges of NIR‐II PAI are also expounded.

paper.title: The Current Status and Future Directions on Nanoparticles for Tumor Molecular Imaging

snippets: Semiconductive polymeric NPs represent a significant portion of organic NPs that exhibit photoacoustic and related properties due to their NIR absorption property. Semiconducting polymers offer unique advantages in photoacoustic applications due to their remarkable photostability and biocompatibility, setting them apart from other NPs.

sections.title: Multimodal Imaging and Theranostic Applications
sections.tldr: Semiconducting polymers excel in multimodal imaging applications by simultaneously providing fluorescence, photoacoustic, and chemiluminescence capabilities that enable comprehensive tumor visualization and characterization. Their integration of diagnostic and therapeutic functions creates powerful theranostic platforms that permit real-time monitoring of treatment efficacy while delivering targeted photodynamic and photothermal therapies. (12 sources)
sections.text:
Semiconducting polymer nanoparticles (SPNs) demonstrate exceptional utility in multimodal imaging applications, enabling comprehensive tumor visualization through complementary imaging modalities. These versatile materials can be engineered to simultaneously provide fluorescence, photoacoustic (PA), and chemiluminescence imaging capabilities, offering multidimensional information about tumor location, morphology, and biological characteristics <Paper corpusId="254688030" paperTitle="(Huang et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>. This multimodal functionality is particularly valuable for improving diagnostic accuracy, as different imaging techniques can compensate for the limitations of individual modalities while providing synergistic information about tumor biology.

The integration of diagnostic and therapeutic capabilities within a single SPN platform represents a significant advancement over traditional tumor detection materials. These theranostic nanoagents combine imaging functionality with therapeutic modalities such as photodynamic therapy (PDT) and photothermal therapy (PTT), enabling simultaneous tumor detection and treatment <Paper corpusId="246066001" paperTitle="(Yuan et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>. For instance, oligopeptide-based SPNs have been developed with both NIR-II fluorescence and NIR-I PA dual-modal imaging capabilities that guide subsequent PTT and PDT therapies, creating a comprehensive cancer treatment platform <Paper corpusId="246066001" paperTitle="(Yuan et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>.

Particularly notable is the transformation of semiconducting polymers into functional carbon dot imaging agents through hydrothermal carbonization. For example, poly(thiophene)-based derivatives can be converted from sheet-like structures into water-dispersible carbon dots that provide simultaneous fluorescence imaging under visible light excitation and PA imaging under NIR irradiation, while also demonstrating high photon-to-heat conversion efficiency for photothermal therapy in living mice <Paper corpusId="238742619" paperTitle="(Jeong et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>. This multimodal functionality from a single nanoplatform represents a significant advantage over conventional imaging materials that typically provide only single-mode visualization.

The theranostic capabilities of SPNs have been further enhanced through biomimetic targeting approaches. For instance, activated fibroblast cell membrane-coated SPNs (AF-SPNs) specifically target cancer-associated fibroblasts in the tumor microenvironment, leading to enhanced tumor accumulation and stronger NIR fluorescence and PA signals compared to uncoated counterparts <Paper corpusId="254688030" paperTitle="(Huang et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="51909178" paperTitle="(Li et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper>. This biomimetic targeting not only improves diagnostic imaging but also enhances therapeutic efficacy by enabling more precise delivery of photothermal and photodynamic treatments to tumor sites.

A significant advantage of SPN-based theranostic platforms is their ability to respond to specific tumor microenvironment characteristics. Some SPNs have been designed as oxygen-sensitive afterglow imaging agents that can detect hypoxic conditions in tumors, allowing visualization of tiny peritoneal metastatic tumors that might otherwise be undetectable <Paper corpusId="254688030" paperTitle="(Huang et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="51922576" paperTitle="(Cui et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper>. This capability for activatable imaging provides real-time information about tumor biology beyond simple anatomical visualization, offering valuable insights for treatment planning and monitoring.

Furthermore, recent advances have led to the development of self-sacrificially biodegradable pseudo-semiconducting polymers that combine NIR-II fluorescence bioimaging with photodynamic immunotherapy and photoactivated chemotherapy <Paper corpusId="254688030" paperTitle="(Huang et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="250453957" paperTitle="(Tang et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>. These systems can co-assemble with amphiphilic polyesters containing pendant chemotherapeutic agents linked via reactive oxygen species (ROS)-responsive bonds, enabling light-triggered drug release for combination therapy while providing simultaneous imaging capabilities.

The metabolizable nature of some SPN formulations addresses potential toxicity concerns associated with nanomaterials. These biodegradable SPNs can be cleared through renal and hepatobiliary pathways after fulfilling their imaging and therapeutic functions, minimizing long-term accumulation in the body <Paper corpusId="271282317" paperTitle="(Neelamraju et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="58648939" paperTitle="(Jiang et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>. Despite their clearance capabilities, these nanoagents maintain excellent photothermal conversion efficiency and emit strong signals in the NIR-II window, providing sensitive imaging of deep brain vasculature and subcutaneous tumors at low systemic dosages.

The clinical significance of these multimodal theranostic platforms extends beyond tumor detection to include personalized medicine applications. The ability of SPN-based biosensors to rapidly detect cancer biomarkers could be critical for selecting personalized treatment options based on the molecular fingerprint of a patient's disease, as well as for monitoring treatment effectiveness and disease recurrence during and after therapy <Paper corpusId="201099989" paperTitle="(Runsewe et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>. This integration of diagnostic and therapeutic functionalities within a single platform represents a paradigm shift toward more precise and personalized cancer management.

The versatility of SPNs is further exemplified by their application in various theranostic configurations, including thiadiazoloquinoxaline (TQ)-based SPNs designed for NIR-II fluorescence imaging-guided cancer photothermal therapy <Paper corpusId="247160239" paperTitle="(Fan et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>. Additionally, intelligent drug delivery systems have been developed using SPNs, such as PDPP3T@PSNiAA-Dox nanoparticles that demonstrate NIR-triggered drug release specifically under acidic tumor conditions, minimizing drug release in normal tissues and resulting in complete tumor elimination without recurrence in animal models <Paper corpusId="253274990" paperTitle="(He et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="31038259" paperTitle="(Zhou et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper>.

The incorporation of electron-deficient units into semiconducting polymer backbones has enabled the development of self-quenched SPNs that amplify PA imaging signals by 1.7-fold in live mice, enhancing tumor delineation by 4.7-fold after systemic administration <Paper corpusId="271282317" paperTitle="(Neelamraju et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. These structural modifications not only improve imaging performance but also enhance therapeutic efficacy, demonstrating how molecular engineering of semiconducting polymers can create increasingly sophisticated multimodal theranostic platforms for comprehensive cancer management.

The resulting C-dots provided (i) multimodal imaging under visible light excitation for FL imaging and NIR irradiation for simultaneous PA imaging, and (ii) high conversion efficiency of photon energy into heat for photothermal therapy (PTT) in living mice.

paper.title: Cell Membrane Coated Semiconducting Polymer Nanoparticles for Enhanced Multimodal Cancer Phototheranostics.

snippets: Phototheranostic nanoagents are promising for early diagnosis and precision therapy of cancer. However, their imaging ability and therapeutic efficacy are often limited due to the presence of delivery barriers in the tumor microenvironment. Herein, we report the development of organic multimodal phototheranostic nanoagents that can biomimetically target cancer-associated fibroblasts in the tumor microenvironment for enhanced multimodal imaging-guided cancer therapy. Such biomimetic nanocamouflages comprise a near-infrared (NIR) absorbing semiconducting polymer nanoparticle (SPN) coated with the cell membranes of activated fibroblasts. The homologous targeting mechanism allows the activated fibroblast cell membrane coated SPN (AF-SPN) to specifically target cancer-associated fibroblasts, leading to enhanced tumor accumulation relative to the uncoated and cancer cell membrane coated counterparts after systemic administration in living mice. As such, AF-SPN not only provides stronger NIR fluorescence and photoacoustic signals to detect tumors but also generates enhanced cytotoxic heat and singlet oxygen to exert combinational photothermal and photodynamic therapy, ultimately leading to an antitumor efficacy higher than that of the counterparts. This study introduces an organic phototheranostic system that biomimetically targets the component in the tumor microenvironment for enhanced multimodal cancer theranostics.

paper.title: Semiconducting Photosensitizer‐Incorporated Copolymers as Near‐Infrared Afterglow Nanoagents for Tumor Imaging

snippets: The fact that cancer metastasis is the main cause of death for most cancer patients necessitates the development of imaging tools for sensitive detection of metastases. Although optical imaging has high temporospatial resolution, tissue autofluorescence compromises the sensitivity for in vivo imaging of cancer metastasis. Herein, the synthesis of a series of photosensitizer‐incorporated poly(p‐phenylenevinylene)‐based semiconducting copolymers and their utility as near‐infrared (NIR) afterglow imaging nanoagents that emit light after cessation of light irradiation are reported. As compared with nondoped nanoparticles, the nanoparticles derived from the photosensitizer‐incorporated copolymers have red‐shifted NIR luminescence and amplified afterglow signals, allowing the detection of tiny peritoneal metastatic tumors almost invisible to naked eye. Moreover, the intrinsic oxygen‐sensitive nature of afterglow makes those nanoagents potentially useful for in vivo imaging of oxygen levels. Thus, this study introduces a generation of light‐excitation‐free background‐minimized optical imaging agents for the sensitive detection of diseased tissues in vivo.

paper.title: Self‐Sacrificially Degradable Pseudo‐Semiconducting Polymer Nanoparticles that Integrate NIR‐II Fluorescence Bioimaging, Photodynamic Immunotherapy, and Photo‐Activated Chemotherapy

snippets: Semiconducting polymers (SP) hold great promise for cancer phototherapy due to their excellent optical properties; however, their clinical application is still hampered by their poor biodegradability. Herein, a self‐sacrificially biodegradable pseudo‐semiconducting polymer (PSP) for NIR‐II fluorescence bioimaging, photodynamic immunotherapy, and photoactivated chemotherapy (PACT) is reported. The PSP can further co‐assemble with an amphiphilic polyester with pendant doxorubicin (DOX) in its side chains via reactive oxygen species (ROS)‐responsive thioketal linkages (PEDOX), which are denoted as NP@PEDOX/PSP. The NP@PEDOX/PSP can accumulate at tumor sites and generate ROS for photodynamic immunotherapy as well as near‐infrared‐II fluorescence (NIR‐II) for bioimaging upon irradition at 808 nm. The ROS could break up thioketal linkages in PEDOX, resulting in rapid doxorubicin (DOX) release for PACT. Finally, both PEDOX and PSP are degraded sacrificially by intracellular glutathione (GSH), resulting in the dissociation of NP@PEDOX/PSP. This work highlights the application of self‐sacrificially degradable PSP for NIR‐II fluorescence bioimaging, photodynamic immunotherapy, and PACT in cancer therapy.

paper.title: Potential applications for photoacoustic imaging using functional nanoparticles: A comprehensive overview

snippets: Semiconductor polymer NPs with a self-quenched process were developed by incorporating an electrondeficient unit into the backbone of semiconducting polymers (Xie et al., 2017). These NPs were transformed into semiconducting polymer NPs, which amplified PA imaging in live mice by 1.7-fold compared to semiconductor polymer NPs. Furthermore, the delineation of tumors was enhanced by 4.7-fold after systemic administration
They proved to be useful for deep-tissue diagnosis due to minimized tissue absorption and reduced light scattering (Jiang et al., 2019)

Moreover, these NPs can be cleared via renal excretions and hepatobiliary pathways after systemic administration, thus minimizing potential toxicity to living mice. The nano agents exhibit excellent photothermal conversion efficiency and emit signals at 1064 nm, providing sensitive near-infrared-II PA imaging of deep brain vasculature and subcutaneous tumors at a low systemic dosage.

paper.title: Metabolizable Semiconducting Polymer Nanoparticles for Second Near‐Infrared Photoacoustic Imaging

snippets: Photoacoustic (PA) imaging in the second near‐infrared (NIR‐II) window (1000–1700 nm) holds great promise for deep‐tissue diagnosis due to the reduced light scattering and minimized tissue absorption; however, exploration of such a noninvasive imaging technique is greatly constrained by the lack of biodegradable NIR‐II absorbing agents. Herein, the first series of metabolizable NIR‐II PA agents are reported based on semiconducting polymer nanoparticles (SPNs). Such completely organic nanoagents consist of π‐conjugated yet oxidizable optical polymer as PA generator and hydrolyzable amphiphilic polymer as particle matrix to provide water solubility. The obtained SPNs are readily degraded by myeloperoxidase and lipase abundant in phagocytes, transforming from nonfluorescent nanoparticles (30 nm) into NIR fluorescent ultrasmall metabolites (≈1 nm). As such, these nanoagents can be effectively cleared out via both hepatobiliary and renal excretions after systematic administration, leaving no toxicity to living mice. Particularly these nanoagents possess high photothermal conversion efficiencies and emit bright PA signals at 1064 nm, enabling sensitive NIR‐II PA imaging of both subcutaneous tumor and deep brain vasculature through intact skull in living animals at a low systematic dosage. This study thus provides a generalized molecular design toward organic metabolizable semiconducting materials for biophotonic applications in NIR‐II window.

Similarly, rapid biomarker detection could be critical for proper selection of personalized treatment options that are suitable for the molecular fingerprint of the patient's disease (i.e., personalized medicine), as well as for monitoring treatment effectiveness and disease recurrence during and after treatment.

paper.title: Editorial: Precise Diagnosis and Therapy Using Near-Infrared Light

snippets: Another article by Gu et al. focuses on a particular type of NIR fluorophores, semiconducting polymer nanoparticles (SPNs). SPNs are constructed by encapsulating hydrophobic semiconducting polymers (SPs) with amphiphilic copolymers, and have shown great promise for phototheranostics of cancer. The authors review recent advances of thiadiazoloquinoxaline (TQ)-based SPNs from their synthesis and hydrophilic functionalization to NIR-II (1,000–1,700 nm) fluorescence imagingguided cancer photothermal therapy (PTT). To enhance the PTT efficiency, they also discuss methods for constructing SPNs with capability of multimodal imaging.

paper.title: Photoacoustic Imaging Probes for Theranostic Applications

snippets: Semiconducting polymer nanoparticles (SPNs) are another new photonic biomaterial with great potential for theranostic applications. SPNs are designed to improve the sensitivity and resolution of PAI because of the tunable optical properties, high absorption coefficients and high photostability of this material (Zhou et al., 2018)

The in vivo experiments indicated that these PDPP3T@PSNiAA-Dox NPs could accumulate in tumor region over time (Figure 7). A burst intracellular Dox release occurred with NIR irradiation at acidic condition (80%), while it was below 40% at neutral condition, which could minimize the release of the drug in normal tissues. In vivo studies on HeLa tumor-bearing mice showed that tumors of PDPP3T@PSNiAA-Dox NPs with laser treatment were effectively eliminated without reoccurrence, while groups treated with free Dox (with and without laser) and NPs without laser showed none or minor tumor elimination.

paper.title: Semiconducting polymer nanoparticles for amplified photoacoustic imaging.
paper.venue: Wiley Interdisciplinary Reviews: Nanomedicine and Nanobiotechnology

snippets: Semiconducting polymer nanoparticles (SPNs) are a new class of photonic materials with great potential for biomedical applications. Owing to their large absorption coefficients, tunable optical properties, and high photostability, SPNs have recently been used to improve the sensitivity and resolution of photoacoustic (PA) imaging. In particular, a number of strategies have been explored to design activatable SPNs for amplified in vivo PA imaging. In this review, the recent advances in the development of SPNs as exogenous PA contrasts agents have been summarized and their promising potential as multifunctional probes for cancer theranostics has been discussed. This article is categorized under: Diagnostic Tools > In Vivo Nanodiagnostics and Imaging.
